deltas.text: An Operational Amplifier (op-amp) amplifies the voltage across its terminals.
An ideal op-amp has an infinite open-loop gain, but in practice its voltage is capped at the voltage supply provided to the opamp (Vcc+, Vcc-).
I forgot to add Vcc pins for the op-amp, so assume that the op-amp ranges from -15V to 15V, since that's the cap on the lab power supply.
When there is any difference across the two terminals, the opamp amplifies it by a very large factor, up to its cap.
Ideal op-amps have infinite input impedance (no current in) and no output impedance (arbitrary current out).
This means that one can safely use KCL at its input terminals without considering the current in...
...and assume that the op-amp will output whatever current is necessary to satisfy KCL at its output.
